This PR was to solve some use cases where the heap size is big. But after finding out that splitting the data into two or more servers mitigates the issue, I don't think we need this PR any more. Closing this PR now.

In high level, we should decouple server_id with server_host (port) stored in Helix/zk. 

(1) Pinot broker should use the server instance id to look up the server address from Helix/Zk instead of parsing the id string like the following:

https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/blob/6e209e4e0ef138f8c21d597aeb20d1993fd1af2b/pinot-core/src/main/java/org/apache/pinot/core/transport/Server.java#L49-L53

(2) Pinot server should decouple the configuration of server Id with server host/port. Right now they are coupled:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/blob/3236e40c2f8d3d603c82e706db41bf2c0c2eaf68/pinot-server/src/main/java/org/apache/pinot/server/starter/helix/HelixServerStarter.java#L142-L151
@snleee Uniformed the APIs to `/tables/{tableName}/instancePartitions`

What do people think about implementing ORDER BY as a first class operator in Pinot -- that way different operators and query types will not have to write their own order by functionality. In the current code changes, CombineGroupByOrderByOperator will only combine the results of a query that has group by and order by right?

But for the other parallel feature (DISTINCT), we need order by as well and we should probably have a common order by executor and combiner/reducer. With the current code changes, it looks like DISTINCT will have to implement its own ORDER BY?

Implementing order by as a first class operator in the operator tree will also work well with plan of getting close to SQL and potentially supporting complex SQL (where each query may have multiple order by's in the physical plan) and an optimizer.

Seems reload doesn't work well with REALTIME tables, and the table will end up having segments with inconsistent schemas.

For realtime tables, after updating the schema and calling `reload` endpoint, all ONLINE segments would be reloaded with the new schema, but the CONSUMING segment would be skipped. As a result, the consuming segment would both keep consuming and finally seal with the old schema.

Tested on a realtime table with LLC (code last checked in from master on [04/11/19](https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/commit/26330f3a2c3309e7cf574e1fff86a1de9fb934ff)). The consuming segment at the time of the reloading would be the only segment with the old schema, when either in CONSUMING state or later in ONLINE state. 

Impact:
- when querying data within a small time range after the time of reloading, the new field added in the new schema is not returned in the query result.
- when querying data with a bit bigger time range, we would see messages below:
`MergeResponseError: responses for table: $table from servers: [$server1, server2] got dropped due to data schema inconsistency.`

Reloading the table/segment again after the consuming segment seals would reload it with the new schema thus bringing the whole table back in healthy state, but it's operationally inefficient.
 
So it seems more like a bug now. We might need to revisit approaches like 
- flushing the consuming segment (and reload)
- adding new columns in memory, and refresh the schema, before consuming more rows (without a forced flush)

@mayankshriv @Jackie-Jiang thoughts?

If server side guarantees that the sorted columns are always put in front of other columns, then broker side does not need this extra index (where the value for each index is just the index) which will add overhead.
I tried your new test on the existing code and it passed, so I don't understand what is the purpose of this fix.
Current behavior keeps the column ordering from selection list and not put ordered columns in front.

I think we should implement this in a generic manner -- something like a container of columns to pass a columnar data batch between operators. The batch size can be fixed (say 4K or 10K) and each time a parent operator calls next, this batch is passed onto to parent operator from child operator.

We should do this independent of sort query or a selection query or an aggregation query. 

For example, a simple query with SELECT -> PROJECT  -> FILTER -> SCAN as the operator tree will also use as the record batch container during the execution or is that not the goal?

The selection test query comparison logic only check the record existence, so it won't recognize the disordered behavior. You can run the sample query in PR description in quickstart to see the behavior.

In that case, can you please make the selection test query comparison check the order? With that we can prevent breaking the order in the future.

> I think we should implement this in a generic manner -- something like a container of columns to pass a columnar data batch between operators. The batch size can be fixed (say 4K or 10K) and each time a parent operator calls next, this batch is passed onto to parent operator from child operator.
> 
> We should do this independent of sort query or a selection query or an aggregation query.
> 
> For example, a simple query with SELECT -> PROJECT -> FILTER -> SCAN as the operator tree will also use as the record batch container during the execution or is that not the goal?

@siddharthteotia That's already the case. All operators communicate with each other via Block. Block typically contains 5k records but are immutable. Indexed table is more useful for manipulating the data (aggregate/group by /order by)
Close this and move to https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/pull/4544.

@sunny19930321 sorry, did not see this issue until now. 

This article can be helpful.
https://engineering.linkedin.com/blog/2019/auto-tuning-pinot

Segment size is something that is to be determined as per your application requirements, and memory availability (and of course, CPU availability).

As you know, pinot queries are processed on a per-segment basis, responses from segments within a server are merged first, and then sent to the broker. The broker merges responses across servers. Each segment is processed in its own thread.

Having huge segments reduces the number of threads used for processing, so reduces parallelism. On the other hand, having a large number of small segments causes the per-segment overhead to be high (servers retain per-segment metadata in memory all the time), and potential thread-contention while processing queries. 

In our experiences on large data pushes, we have found segment size of between 100M to 500M to be a fair size with servers running on 64G machines. On machines with more memory & cpu, the segment size could be increased, if we find benefit (e.g. if there are a large number of segments, then we could have a smaller number of larger segments).

Stopping consumption is not a good idea in most cases. 

Errors can be due to two reasons:
1. Pinot bug in transform/read operations: We should be catching these in unit and integration tests and staging clusters. So far, we have not encountered this case in production at Linkedin (or reported here as an issue)
2. Bad data in stream: We have encountered this multiple times at Linkedin, as well as reported here as an issue (In the last case, I think we had one where a single string column was very huge causing segment build to fail, starting consumption all over for the same segment, and thus consumer never made forward progress. We introduced a limit in response to this). 

In general, streams do not allow administrators to "remove" offending rows. Once a row is in the stream, it is in. The choice is on the consumer to skip the row and make forward progress, or get stuck on consuming the row. I believe the former choice is better, especially for analytics platforms like Pinot. Not counting one row in aggregate for a day or so (the offline component is likely to correct the data) is a much better alternative than stopping consumption, and having admins manually set offset so skip over the offending data.
Note that in either case, we have loss of data . In LLC we may be able to do more manual manipulations to skip over exact offending row, but in HLC it is impossible. If there is more than one offending row spread across, then problem is even worse, and by the time the manual corrections are applied, the stream is heavily backed up (in a typical production scenario) and the downtime is high.

Conclusion: It is best to move on after discarding the row.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-pinot/pull/4563?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [d8d0bb5...4053116](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-pinot/pull/4563?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
We don't allow multi-value metric as it does not make sense. We should be able to handle multi-value dimensions though

I think the purpose of checking current state is to see whether **ideal states** have been updated or not (see the description of this method). Within 10 seconds, if all the ideal states have been updated, we are safe to have instance perform correctly ( like starting/stoping serving queries).
Addressed review comments

Wanted to whether there were any follow-ups or attempts to address this, especially with LLC (I assume this is the "new realtime consumer" mentioned earlier).

It seems more of a bug than a feature request now. Real-time segments would end up in different schemas, causing segment dropped at query time due to schema mismatch.
See the experiment in https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/issues/4225#issuecomment-521824275

There has been no movement on this so far. Contributions welcome.

A few ways to address this, but we need to take care of the corner case where the schema is updated exactly at the time the segments are nearing or at completion. Some partitions may have completed and started a new segment (but no data yet, so we cannot commit them -- we don't allow 0-row segments). 

One way  I can think of is to provide an API that atomically changes all CONSUMING partitions to OFFLINE, and another controller API to just run the realtime segment validation manager, perhaps on the specific table (these things get harder with controller separation).

Another way is to send a helix message (RELOAD) to all realtime segments and handle all corner cases in the server (devil is in the details, I have not given it much thought, I admit). The completed segments should also be updated with the default value for the  new columns added.

So far in production, my observation is the schema evolutions are rare, and applications are ok waiting for a few hours (or even days) in order for the new schema to take effect (before they start querying the new fields added). I will be interested in knowing about use cases (other than testing, because I assume you can always restart in test environment) where the need is instantaneous. I would also like to know what the limits are (1 minute? 1 hour?)

@mcvsubbu Thanks for your inputs!

In our environment, around 2/3 of our production tables are REALTIME, and we are seeing more and more requests to evolve schemas, especially with our recent efforts to onboard customers in a self-serve mode. 

Our flush thresholds are 5 hours by default, by which time the new schema should be picked up. But the problem is when to reload segments. If we reload segments right after the schema change (call reload endpoint in the onboarding portal when the user bumps the kafka schema version), the consuming segments would keep consuming and **seal with the old schema**. This results in schema mismatch at query time, causing this segment to be dropped, since this would be the only segment with the old schema - old segment are reloaded with the new schema, and new segments would pick up the new schema as well. Reloading segments X hours after the schema change could solve the issue, but it adds operational overhead.

So, if we can force flush the consuming segments upon schema change, once the new segments start consuming with the new schema, we can call reload endpoint on all old segments, which would both solve the schema mismatch issue, and allow consumption with the new schema right away.

If you anticipate issues with force flushing segments across partitions, we can manage customers' expectations on the time to pick up the new schema, and only address the schema mismatch issue, like upon completion of the consuming segment, fetch the latest schema and add the new column(s) to the mutable segment?
